Venezuela has begun a number of large forestry projects to satisfy the fiber requirements of that nation's pulp and paper Mills. Raw material needs are particularly acute with respect to secondary fibers for the paper and board industry, long-fibered pulp for newsprint, and softwood timber for use in the construction industry. The pulp and paper industry is heavily dependent on imports, with 83 percent of all pulp requirements being imported. As these projects reach maturity, opportunities for U.S. businessmen will arise in construction, consulting/engineering, and equipment sales.

Because of current pulp, short fiber, and timber shortages, Venezuela has embarked on an ambitious planting/development program for Caribbean pine and eucalyptus in the southern Anzoategui and northern Monagas State areas, respectively. The objective is to convert the Sabanas into a gigantic forestry and industry complex capable of supporting several pulp Mills that would not only supply domestic needs but also provide valuable export income. The two major government agencies responsible for these developments are Corporacion Venezolana de Guayana (CVG) and Compania Nacional de Reforestacion (CNR).

was begun in 1969 by Corporacion Venezolana de Guayana with the intention of planting 218 million trees on 150,000 hectares by 1985, in order to produce long fiber pulp-mainly for the production of newsprint. Long fiber pulp is currently imported at an annual rate of 80,000 tons. Caribbean pine (Hondurensis), imported from Guatemala and other Central American countries, is the type of tree being planted. To date, about 80 million trees have been planted on 110,000 acres, with an additional 110 million planned for 1984. Plans are being made to harvest trees for pulp production in 1984. Eventually, 4,000 hectares out of every 10,000 will be harvested for pulp, with the remainder being conserved for timber production (maturity: about 10 to 15 years). By 1986, CVG expects to reach the 4,000 hectare level, with an expected yield of 180 cubic meters per hectare. CVG will require forestry equipment and technical assistance for the extraction process.

In preparation for the harvesting period, CVG has plans to build a pulp mill capable of producing 200,000 tons annually, which should be completed by the 1984 deadline. Decisions on outside equity participation and exact composition have yet to be made, but the mill will be separately managed from the rest of the forestry

ect, and probably will be structured in the manner of other CVG corporations such as SIDOR, VENALUM. and ALCASE. While a feasibility study had been made at the initial conception of the Uverito Forestry

it considered tropical woods rather than pines as the basic raw material. A probable timetable for Uverito development is: late 1978-79 for new feasibility studies; 1979-81 for decisions on equity participation; 1981-82 for start of construction; and 1984 for start-up of production.

Compania Nacional de Reforestacion (CONARE) was created in August 1975, with the mandate to take responsibility for Venezuela's forestry industry (excluding Uverito). Under Federal decree No. 1341 of December 16, 1975, CONARE was authorized to incorporate the private sector into Venezuela's forestry programs. While CONARE has several small experimental forests throughout the country, its major area of development is in South Anzoategui and Monagas States, on land owned by the National Agrarian Institute. Here CONARE has about 100,000 hectares which it plans to divide into seven huge blocks and to develop, in conjunction with its Venezuelan and foreign partners, a large Caribbean pine and eucalyptus plantation.

Companies established by CONARE include: (1) Corporacion Forestal Guayamure, with an area of about 10,000 hectares of Caribbean pine; (2) Forestor, with an area of 75,000 hectares which will be planted to eucalyptus to support a 300,000 ton-year pulp mill; and (3) Corporacion Forestal Sipao S.A., which will plant 18,000 hectares of short-fibered eucalyptus.
Corporation Venezolana de Fomento is doing a feasibility study for a bagasse mill at Rio Turbio. Industry
sources are skeptical of this project's success, in part due to water shortages in the area. A
to construct a short fiber mill in Central Portuguesa is also being considered. While no construction has begun, several firms have placed orders for its production.
With harvesting periods due around 1984, and with initial experimental thinnings already started, the demand for forestry equipment should begin to increase. The manager of the Uverito Forestry
has already visited the United States to study equipment. The proximity of the United States, which facilitates maintenance, is an important competitive factor.

In response to the upcoming increases in supply of raw materials there appears to be a new interest in investment in paper machines; several local firms are considering purchases of new machines in the near future. However, industry members are awaiting changes in Government price control policy before making large investments.
Forestry studies have indicated the need for improved planting methods. Consequently, there should be new purchases of equipment to plant and maintain forests. A Georgia
has already sold quite a few of its semiautomatic transplanters to CONARE, Uverito, and Manpa paper

There has been considerable discussion concerning the placing of Venezuela's forest and pulp industry under one government coordinating agency. Since most of the forestry projects are located in the same area (southern Anzoategui, Monagas, and Uverito) coordination between the entities developing these areas will be required for long-term investments such as pulp Mills. Plans call for a ministerial level commission to coordinate forestry development between Uverito, CONARE, and the private sector. It is reported that the Government is considering consolidating the industry under CONARE'S manageIn ent.

Australian Newsprint Mills Ltd. (ANM) has announced a go-ahead for construction of a A$155 million newsprint mill at Albury, in New South Wales. The New South Wales Government had encouraged the construction of the mill with various incentives, including housing, payroll tax rebates, machinery subsidies, employee training subsidies, and financial assistance in locating key perSonnel.

The mill will eventually have the capacity to produce 180,000 tons of newsprint a year, raising ANM'S total annual capacity to more than 380,000 tons. More than 90 percent of the raw material furnished would be thermomechanical pulp produced at the mill; the remainder will be imported in the form of bleached sulfate pulp. About 450,000 cubic meters-year of radiata pine is available from about 53,000 hectares of State-owned forest in the area around Albury. ANM presently operates a newsprint mill in Tasmania, and the combined production from both Mills would satisfy about 70 percent of Australia's annual newsprint consumption. This will reduce the country's dependence on imported newsprint— about 200,000 tons annually, mainly from New
and Canada—and will save about A$70 million in foreign exchange.
The planning and design of the mill is well under way, and the selection of equipment has reached an advanced

which is due for completion in 1981, has been welcomed by state and local governments of New South Wales, although there have been some protests from a wide range of community groups, following environmental and economic impact studies on the proposed mill. The

will provide employment for about 800 people during the construction phase, and 650 people when in actual operation. It has been reported that about A-100 million will be borrowed from domestic sources for the
by ANM, with additional capital sought overseas.
The decision by ANM to construct the new mill at Albury could put the

in direct competition with one of its major shareholders, New Zealand's Tasman Pulp and Paper Co. Ltd., which has a 16 percent stake in ANM (ANM also has a 20 percent share in Tasman Pulp and Paper). The New

is a major producer and supplier of newsprint to Australia, and has been in Some financial difficulties of late. Sources: American Embassy report dated July 1978; industry trade journal reports dated August and September 1978.

Gautemala does not produce its own woodpulp, satisfying all of its primary papermaking fiber requirements through imports. Industria Papelera Centro Americana, the largest of the country's three paper pro
ducers, was sold recently by Boise Cascade Corporation of the United States to the Sigma Group of El Salvador; the latter is a large printing and packaging materials
pany with manufacturing operations in Mexico and Central America. Industria Papelera reported production of 25,000 tons of paper in 1977, up by almost one-third over 1976, when the

imported 10,800 tons of pulp, including bleached and semi-bleached sulfate, all from the United States. The remainder of their fiber needs came from wastepaper, of which a total of 12,500 tons were used. This included 6,500 tons from the United States, and 6,000 tons collected in Guatemala.

Papeles Elaborados reported that it produced about 7,000 tons of paper in 1977, up from 5,000 tons in 1976. A new paper machine is now in operation at the company's mill. The firm has indicated that it imports about 2,800 tons of U.S. pulp and uses about 4,200 tons of wastepaper, of which, about 40 percent is obtained locally and the remainder from other Central American countries. Cartones Economicos is a small producer of grey board, with an annual output of 600 tons.

The most interesting year-to-year change in 1977 was the extraordinary increase in the consumption of paper in Guatemala, rising from 56,000 tons to more than 97,500 during the 1976-77 period. Imports of paper climbed from 40,500 tons to 75,861 tons, while exports were static at about 11,000 tons.
Source: American Embassy Guatemala report dated July 1978.
3. Indonesia: Report on Two Wood-Processing Complexes: P.T. Raja Garuda Mas and the Plywood Oligopoly

The wood-processing complex of P.T. Raja Garuda Mas is located at Besitong in North Sumatra province near the border with Aceh. Established in 1974, the firm began operations with only a plywood mill but, in the intervening years, has added two sawmill units and a plant which produces wood-cement panels for prefabricated houses.

In addition to plywood for construction purposes, the facility also turns out decorative veneer for furniture. Most of the equipment in the plywood plant is of Japanese manufacture though there were two large peelers from a U.S. manufacturer, Production Machinery Inc. of Portland, Oregon. Capacity of the plywood operation is 12,000-15,000 sheets (measuring four feet by eight feet, with a thickness of four millimeters) per day. The plant operates 24 hours per day with the exception of 2 days each month when shut down for maintenance.
Garuda Mas' sawmill units were set up in 1977 to
comply with an Indonesian Government regulation compelling holders of timber concessions to process logs locally. As at the plywood facility, most of the equipment was imported from Japan.

began to manufacture wood-cement panels using as raw material the waste from its plywood and sawmill operations. Wood waste is chipped in a hammer mill, and is washed and mixed with cement to produce panels measuring one meter by twenty centimeters, with a thickness of five centimeters. These panels are used principally in the construction of low-cost, prefabricated houses. At present Garuda Mas produces about 3,000 panels per day.

Garuda Mas obtains its timber from large concessions controlled by the firm in Aceh province, near the town of Idi. Logs are floated down the Besitong River to the plant site on the river bank. The river also serves as the company's inlet for imported raw materials, which are brought in by barge, mainly from Singapore. Most of the finished products are trucked to Medan's port, Belawan, for shipment to Java or abroad.

Established in 1974, Lontar Papyrus Paper Industry is situated in Aceh province, about twenty kilometers from the town of Langsa. The sole owner of the facility is a Medan resident of Chinese descent. Except for two technicians from Taiwan, the plant is staffed by local Indonesians. Much of the plant's equipment, which appears quite modern, is from Taiwan, though there is some from Japan and West Germany as well. Raw material, in the form of boxed pulp, is imported from the Scandinavian countries, Canada and the United States. Originally, the firm had hoped to procure most of its raw material locally but it discovered that it could obtain only enough wood to operate its chippers at 20 percent capacity. The

now hopes to arrange with one or more local timber companies to obtain the waste wood from logging operations for use in paper production. Lontar has no timber concession of its own. Present capacity of the Lontar operation is 30 tons per day, all of which is marketed in the Medan area. The plant produces paper with tensile strength from 28 to 70 grams. Reportedly, the

has no difficulty in selling all of the paper it makes during its round-the-clock operations. About 200 people are employed at the plant. Within the next year Lontar plans to expand its capacity to 100 tons per day. Land adjacent to the existing plant has been cleared and equipment for the expansion is on order. COMMODITY TRENDS: PULP, PAPER, AND BOARD PRODUCTS
By Howard A. Post and Donald W. Butts

Deliveries of domestically produced pulpwood to U.S. pulp Mills during January–June 1978 substantially accelerated over the relatively flat first quarter, which was roughly equal to the first quarter of 1977. This year's 6 month deliveries of domestic wood were 660,000 cords over 1977 deliveries, with nearly all of the increase occurring during April–June (table S-2). It appears that the severe winter of 1977-78 (as in 1976-77) slowed logging and hauling activities, but that lost timber production was made up after spring arrived. Softwoods were 75 percent of total domestic wood deliveries while hardwoods provided 25 percent. Pulpwood imports during the first half-year of this year accelerated significantly over 1977 figures, with the nearly half-million cords being 28 percent over yearearlier figures. Thus, total mill pulpwood receipts of 38.6 million cords (domestic and imported) for the JanuaryJune period are 800,000 cords or 2 percent over total receipts for the 1977 period. This figure compares with 36.9 million cords in 1976, up 1.7 million cords or close to 5 percent. As stated, in spite of reported slowdowns of logging activites due to severe winter and wet spring conditions in some areas, pulpwood deliveries to the Mills held up and increased slightly over 1977 figures. The climatic impact on wood supply could well have been softened by increased receipts of chips and sawdust. A check of American Pulpwood Association monthly reports on pulpwood receipts at the Mills shows that mill deliveries of wood residuals—chips and sawdust—during JanuaryJune 1978 increased nearly 18 percent over 1977 while the roundwood form of pulpwood deliveries increased only one-half of one percent. These residuals, or waste chiefly from lumber and plywood mill operations and other timber converting plants, supplied 44 percent of pulpwood deliveries during the 1978 period, up from 40 percent during the comparable months of 1977. Availability of such residues for pulping is directly related to log conversion in the lumber and plywood sec

tors; which, in turn, is related to the level of housing starts and general construction activity. A high level of activity in solid wood product demand has led to availability of substantial supplies of residual chips and sawdust at the converting Mills. Such waste residuals as pulpwood also supply a generally strong export market. However, chip (pulpwood) exports (table S-14), primarily to Japan, shows only a 27,000-cord increase. Thus the indications are that increased pulpwood requirements at the domestic pulp Mills in 1978 have been met by a combination of increased receipts of pulpwood, mainly wood residuals, and a drawdown of woodyard inventories. Mill pulpwood inventories at the end of June totaled 5.0 million cords, down 360,000 cords from March 31 levels and 1.2 million cords during the first 6 months, or 19 percent below the level of December 31, 1977. The volume of pulpwood consumed in pulp manufacture has shown growth closely correlated to the combination of increased mill pulpwood receipts and a substantial drawdown of mill wood inventories. Total U.S. consumption of pulpwood during January–June 1978, at 39.8 million cords, is up 1.4 million cords or 3.7 percent from the comparable 1977 period. Leading regions in pulpwood consumption continue to be the South Central and South Atlantic, where Mills in each region utilized close to 12.7 million cords during the first 6 months of 1978, representing 64 percent of total U.S. pulpwood consumed. The 8.2 million cords consumed in western Mills (21 percent of the U.S. total) puts the region in third place; with the Northeast Mills (3.6 million cords), and the North Central Mills (2.7 million cords) a distant fourth and fifth. On a percentage basis, the greatest increase in pulpwood use occurred in the Northeast region's Mills—up 17 percent. The regional pulpwood consumption data suggest a related increase in pulp production and capacity utilization in those States. However, regional pulp production data are not available. The first 6-months of data suggest that total pulpwood receipts at the Mills could approach 76.3 million cords by the end of 1978, up 3.8 percent from 73.5 million cords in

1977, and 4.8 percent over the 72.8 million cords delivered in 1976. Annual pulpwood consumption will grow at a slightly higher rate. The 6-month data suggest 1978 pulpwood annual consumption will be close to 79.7 million cords, 4.7 million cords or 6 percent over 1977 figures, and 6.5 million cords and 9 percent over 1976. Pulpwood consumption for the first half of 1978, adjusted to an annual rate, indicates that pulpwood production and deliveries must increase in the second half by about 2 million cords over the January–June figures to satisfy mill requirements without the further drawing down of woodyard inventory levels. Currently, woodyard inventories are at their lowest point in 10 years. Except in the Northeast, regional pulpwood inventories at the Mills are down 300,000 to 400,000 cords from last year's levels in each region. With increasing emphasis on recovery of wastepaper as a source of paper and boardmaking fibers, the pressure to increase pulpwood supplies May soften during the last half of 1978.

The consumption of non-wood fibers in papermaking, such as straw, rags, and bagasse (table S-2) increased by 14,000 tons in the first half of 1978 over 1977. However, on an annual basis, consumption of nonwood fibers should be about 200,000 tons below 1976 levels. Nonwood fibers constitute a minor portion of the “other” fibrous materials utilized in pulp production.

Wastepaper is the major secondary fiber raw materials source. Receipts of wastepaper at Mills during the first half of 1978 totaled 6.1 million tons and constituted 95 percent of the non-wood fibrous materials utilized. The January–June data suggest that a total of about 12 million tons of all grades of wastepaper will be delivered to the Mills in 1978; compared with a reported 10.4 million tons received in 1977 and 12.2 million tons for 1976. Data from the Bureau of the Census for 1977 is preliminary. Figures for 1977 nonwood fibrous materials consumption are estimated to be 1.5 to 2.0 million tons too low, which would give a total of 12.0 to 12.4 million tons delivered.

The primary data base improvements developing in 1978 are guidelines to industry reporting of wastepaper consumption. The data suggest that the full-year rate of wastepaper receipts will realistically reach 12.2 to 12.5 million tons for 1978. Wastepaper consumption at the paper, paperboard and related products Mills, is slightly more than 6 million tons for the first 6 months and roughly equals receipts. With the improved reporting, the full 1978 consumption of all wastepaper grades in such Mills should exceed the 12.1 million tons estimated for

1977 by 2 to 3 percent above the 1976 level. The total for 1978 could possibly reach 12.5 million tons. During January-June, wastepaper receipts led consumption by about 60,000 tons. Excess receipts were reflected in 766,000 tons of inventories, up 8 percent over December 1977 figures and just 6,000 tons below the 1976 level. All these data combined indicate a relatively stable total demand for wastepaper as a raw material in the paper and board industry. The leading grades of wastepaper consumed continued to be the bulky grades, with old corrugated at 42 percent of the total, mixed waste at 24 percent, and waste news at 17 percent. Consumption of high grades of wastepaper varied little from year earlier figures because of competition from abundant and cheap virgin market pulp. The wastepaper inventories of 766,000 tons at paper, paperboard, and allied products Mills, increased about 9 percent over December and June 1977 inventories, and returned to the generally higher level reached in 1974. This increased inventory level could well be associated with the growing interest in and expansion or use of old corrugated in linerboard Mills as a portion of the fiber used in unbleached liner manufacture. The influence of this waste grade in the inventory trend is also seen in the substantial increase in consumption of old corrugated, which, over the 1978 six-month period, increased 360,000 tons, or 17 percent, over the like period in 1977. Exports of old corrugated during the period, at 255,000 tons, were nearly 30,000 tons behind 1977 six-month figures. A net gain of close to 330,000 tons in sales of old corrugated by the wastepaper industry appears to have been achieved. This net gain in movement of old corrugated does not make up, however, for the substantial export loss of 64,000 tons of high grade, higher value pulp substitutes, compared with 1977 exports. With European economies improving, European demand for U.S. papermaking fiber, including the high grade wastepapers, is expected to increase. Countries such as England, Sweden, Holland, Italy and West Germany, in their attempts to increase recovery and recycling of domestic wastepaper and reduce reliance upon wastepaper imports, will challenge U.S. wastepaper. Both the domestic and world fiber markets pose a very real challenge to the wastepaper industry to furnish quality packs in required volume at prices competitive with virgin pulp and indigenous wastepaper stocks. There is no indication that the cellulosic insulation industry, utilizing substantial volumes of old news, has recovered from the debacle of last winter. Trade journals, however, are reporting the insulators’ demand for wastepaper will strengthen with the coming of cool weather, and old newspaper prices will improve.

Prices offered to collectors for ordinary waste news are running from $7 to $12 per ton, compared with a range of $20 to $41 in Jaunary; depending upon metropolitan area or region. At the same time, reported mill buying prices (carload lots f.o.b. dealer's docks) for the somewhat better grade of No. 1 news are reported now to range from $15 to $38 compared with $35 to $85 in January. Old news collections are adequate to meet current requirements. A large supply is available and just waiting for improved demand and more attractive prices to draw it out.

According to industry producer and market sources, the world woodpulp excess inventories, particularly in Swedish pulp export Mills, was drawn down close to normal levels of 1.0 to 1.5 million metric tons by the end of June, from a high of almost 2.9 million metric tons in December 1977. This was accomplished through aggressive market development and competitive pricing by the world market pulp producers. In the soft world market and aggressive selling atmosphere in the first half of the year, U.S. export market pulp lost some ground from volumes shipped during January–June 1977–1.306 million short tons compared with 1.378 million short tons of exports (table S-14). Pulp exports, however, are only a small part (5 percent) of total U.S. pulp production. Market pulp Mills, operating at about 96 percent of capacity during January–June according to the American Paper Institute (API), compared with a 94 percent operating rate during the 1977 period, funneled more of their pulps toward the domstic paper, paperboard and allied products Mills.

Total woodpulp production of captive, or integrated and market pulp Mills is reported at 24 million tons for the first 6 months of 1978, compared with 23.9 million tons for the 1977 period (table S-3). These data, however, are incomplete because the date covering miscellaneous “other” grades of pulp, including defibrated, exploded, screenings and related wood fibers, are not available. The final pulp production figure will probably approach 25.5 million tons for January–June 1977. On an annual basis, pulp production would approximate 51.3 million tons for 1978; up from an estimated 50 plus million tons for 1977, and from 48.8 million tons for 1976. Thus, the pulp industry has been producing to meet a slowly improving demand for its product. Producer inventory data are not yet available from the Bureau of the Census; but API data indicate no inventory building at the pulp Mills. Pulp inventories at the converting Mills also show essentially no change from 1977 levels (table S-4, table S-5).

The leading pulp grades in demand in both domestic and export markets continue to be the bleached and unbleached sulfates (table S-3, table S-14). The total of all sulfate pulp grades, at 18.1 million tons for the first 6 months, was 500,000 tons or 2.8 percent over 1977 sixmonth figures. This tonnage also continues, as in 1977, to represent nearly 75 percent of the total reported 24.0 million tons of pulp production. Production of groundwood grades, including growing volumes of thermomechanical pulps, decreased from 2.3 million tons in the 1977 period to 2.1 million tons for January-June 1978. Semi-chemical pulp production also Fell slightly, from 2.1 million tons to 2.0 million tons for 1978. The production of corrugating medium, based on this pulp, Fell; while the use of wastepapers in a combination furnished medium increased (table S-5). This increased use of wastepaper in combination medium furnishes, especially old corrugated, is reflected in the wastepaper consumption data, by grade (table S-2). Old corrugated consumption at the user Mills, at 2.5 million tons, grew 460,000 tons or 17 percent over 1977 six-month consumption figures.

The production of Special alpha and dissolving pulps dropped slightly from 1977 figures (table S-3). This is reflected in the 8 percent reduced consumption of those grades (table S-5) at the non-paper Mills, where producers of rayon fibers, cellophane and related chemical-converted pulp-based products are being steadily challenged in the market by other man-made fibers, filaments and films. The reduction of Special alpha and dissolving pulp production was also influenced by a drop in exports of these grades from 413,000 tons in January–June 1977 to 403,000 for the 1978 period: a drop of 2.4 percent in exports (table S-14).

The total picture, however, for the pulp producers during January–June 1978 has been one of some improvement. The estimated final 1978 pulp production figure, at 51.3 million tons, will be an all-time record high; close to 2.5 percent above 1977 production. This improvement is geared to the 2.7 percent growth in paper and board production (table S-6).

Preliminary data on paper and board apparent consumption (production + imports - exports) sets the quantity at 34.5 million tons for the January–June 1978 period, a record rate. The second quarter rate of 16.8 million tons was 5.3 percent greater than that reported for the first quarter. The relationship of consumption to real GNP in 1978 (a commonly used measure) exceeds the norm and introduces the possibility of inventory accumulation as a factor for the variance. Inventories May have been built as

a hedge against possible paper industry strikes. Growing demand, stemming from the second quarter upturn in the U.S. economy as well as buying by offshore economies, provided added impetus to the 1978 growth of paper and board production. As reported by the Bureau of the Census, U.S. paper and board output in the second quarter totaled 16.3 million tons, a gain of 5.3 percent over the first quarter figure. For the half year, production equalled 30.8 million tons, 3.5 percent higher than the comparable year-ago level. As published by the American Paper Institute, the capacity utilization rates for paper Mills averaged 93.4 percent in the first 6 months of 1978 while those for paperboard Mills averaged 91.9 percent in the same period. Capacity utilization rates in the comparable period a year ago averaged 91.7 percent and 91.1 percent, respectively. Production of the paper grades, which amounted to 7.4 million tons in the second quarter, was up 2.3 percent over the first quarter figure and totaled 14.6 million tons for the first 6 months of the year, a 5.9 percent increase over the comparable 1977 period. Reflecting sharp gains in the nondurables sector and a pickup in export trade, the packaging-oriented paperboard segment showed a

percent favorable quarter-to-quarter change and totaled 14.3 million tons in the January–June period. Since the growth pattern emulated that shown in 1977, there was only a small improvement in the comparative 1977-78 half-year totals. Production of the building paper and board components, reflecting the continued high level of construction activity, climbed 8.9 percent higher in the second quarter and amounted to 2.8 million tons for the first half of 1978, a 4.9 percent increase over the first 6 months of 1977. In the paper sector, year-to-year improvements were evident in production of virtually all grades of paper but continued to be centered mainly in the printing and writing papers, which are currently reflecting the expanding demand from the burgeoning magazine industry and continuing growth in overall advertising. As a group, printing and writing paper represents the bulk of all paper output, accounting for nearly two-thirds of the total paper output. Production of these papers was up 8.5 percent in the first half of 1978 compared with the similar period in 1977. The other two major paper grade sectors, tissues and coarse papers were up 3.1 percent and 2.8 percent, respectively. Preliminary reports on second quarter production of some paper grades such as newsprint, coated two-sides printing papers, bristols, and the bag and sack papers, indicated lower second quarter output. Paperboard production finished the second quarter on the upbeat with a notable trend in the quickening tempo of linerboard production. Production of linerboard, the bedrock for the industry, increased 6.6 percent in the

second quarter and totaled 6.8 million tons for the half year. Annualized, the second quarter rate would represent record production levels. Output of the combination paperboard grades, which use wastepaper as the major fiber source, moved up in the second quarter but finished the half year only 1.6 percent higher than the same period a year ago. Production of the bleached paperboard grades showed a comparative year-to-year decline of 14 percent as a strong second quarter performance, particularly in milk carton stock, was unable to offset a poor first quarter output and a similar strong second quarter showing a year ago. Second quarter production of the building paper and board grades was 8.7 percent higher than the first quarter total. Output of building papers, amounting to 1,006 thousand tons, represented a 13.8 percent improvement over the comparable 6-month period in 1977.

Aside from higher newsprint imports, which tradi-tionally amount to more than 60 percent of the total U.S. requirement of newsprint, imports in the past 2 years have been expanded because of higher domestic demand for printing papers, particularly coated lightweight magazine paper which is in tight supply in the United States. For the first 6 months of the year, import tonnage of all paper, board and converted products totaled 4.6 million tons, up 25.5 percent over the similar period in 1977. The value of imports, totaling $1.4 billion, was up by 25 percent over the first 6 months of 1977. Second quarter imports, climbing further, were up 16.5 percent over the first quarter total.

Most of the paper and board imports are in the form of printing paper. Newsprint imports, which dropped in relative importance, still represent 85 percent of the total paper and board imports. In the first half of 1978, imports of newsprint, and uncoated and coated printing papers accounted for 91.5 percent of all paper and board products, with building paper and board accounting for an additional 5 percent.

Newsprint imports which totaled 3.7 million tons in the January–June period were up by 16.4 percent over the total recorded in the same period in 1977. Second quarter newsprint imports were up 14.8 percent over the first quarter figure. Uncoated printing papers, other than newsprint, totaled 346,000 tons in the first half of 1978 and showed a second quarter gain of 23 percent. Coated printing paper imports approached 140,000 tons in the first 6 months of 1978, and were up 11.8 percent in the second quarter. Imports of building paper and board, reflective of the strong demand engendered by heightened building activity in the United States totaled 250,200 tons, a 75 percent increase over last year's level for the same 6-month period.
Exports Move Up in Second Quarter

Export volume of paper, board and converted products totaled 942,000 tons in the second quarter, which represented a 13.9 percent increase over the depressed first quarter shipments to foreign markets. Overall, exports were up 6.6 percent in the first half of the year; however, year-to-year declines still were evident in the paper grades. As a result, exports of the primary paper and board grades were up only a modest 1.6 percent in the first half of the year despite a sharp gain (12.2 percent) in the second quarter.

Exports of the primary paperboard products, which amounted to 1,155,000 tons for the first 6 months of 1978, were up 10.7 percent in the second quarter and 8.3 percent when compared to the first half of 1977. Linerboard trade, normally the key to the industry's export performance, finished the half year at a reported 804,000 tons, up 8.9 percent over the similar period in 1977 but below the past 10-year average. A firming woodpulp market, disrupted since 1975 by massive producer-held inventories and improving European economies, points toward improvement in second half linerboard exports.
Exports of Special foodboard continued to grow, climbing 35.9 percent over the first quarter tonnage. First

half exports of Special foodboard were reported to be 169,900 tons setting the stage for another record-breaking year. While markets are maturing for bleached boards in the United States, exports of this Commodity, destined for countries with changing modes of food distribution and climbing living standards, have grown at an average annual rate of 18.1 percent since 1967. Converted paper and board products, a relatively fast growing export segment over the past 5 years, moved up only modestly in the second quarter. However, for the half year, converted products totaled 168,000 tons, up 51.2 percent over the reported half-year figure for 1977.

Paper prices overall, as measured by the Producer Price Index (former Wholesale Price Index), rose a modest 4.2 percent in the January–June period. Paperboard prices were up 4.4 percent and converted product prices were up only 2.9 percent during the 6-month period. Building board prices, directly influenced by the strong demand, were up 12.7 percent in the January–June period. In comparison, average prices for all industrial commodities in the first half of 1978 rose 2.1 percent.
COMMODITY TRENDS: SOLID WOOD PRODUCTS January-June 1977-78

Demand for softwood solid wood products was off to a brisk pace in the first half of 1978 as U.S. housing starts, on a seasonally adjusted annual basis for the second quarter of this year, was over the two million mark (a 2,114,000 average). This was an 11 percent increase over the same period in 1977. Actual starts of residential construction for the first 6 months showed 986,400 starts, an increase of 4.0 percent. Single family dwellings comprised 72 percent of the total housing starts, compared to 75 percent a year earlier. The percent of single family starts is a key indicator for solid wood product demand since more lumber and plywood are used in single family construction than in multiple unit construction. In general, common walls and use of substitute materials such as brick and block in multi-family construction reduce the amount of structural wood products used.

For the first 6 months of 1978, production, shipments, and orders received of softwood lumber were running slightly less than the same period in 1977. Production of softwood lumber was less than half of one percent below the first half of 1977, while shipments were 1 percent less and orders received were about 2 1/2 percent less. The reduced levels of production and orders of softwood lumber during such a high rate of demand possibly reflect the severe winter weather over the first part of the year, reducing logging operations and construction activity, and the anticipation by lumber wholesalers that housing demand—thus lumber demand—will taper off by the end of 1978.

Specifically, softwood lumber production in the southern pine region for the first 6 months of 1978 was essentially the same as in 1977; the Douglas fir region showed a 4.8 percent increase in production; the western pine region a 4.0 percent decrease; the California redwood region, a 6.3 percent decrease, and other softwood regions at virtually the same pace. The southern pine region produced 26 percent of the total softwood lumber for January–June 1978; 30 percent for the Douglas fir region, 31 percent for the western pine region, and 7.3 percent for the California redwood region. Therefore, the Pacific Northwest continues to produce the majority of the softwood lumber needs for the domestic and export market. However, indications are that the direction of

flow of softwood lumber from the Southern and Pacific Northwest-producing region are changing. Freight rates on the Nation's rail lines from the Pacific Northwest to the northeastern consuming regions are, according to industry sources, becoming cost prohibitive. The southern producing region (basically the southeastern States) has an increasing advantage in the freight proportion of the lumber costs to the northeastern wholesaler. Also, various sources indicate that the Pacific Northwest producers are directing sales to western markets and export. U.S. exports of softwood lumber to all countries for the first six months of 1978 were 703 million board feet, a 12 percent decrease from the same period last year. Japan and Canada were the two leading purchasers of U.S. softwood lumber, buying 203 and 193 million board feet, respectively. These two countries purchased 56 percent of U.S. lumber exports. Australian purchases ranked third at 68 million board feet and Italy ranked fourth at 58 million board feet. Douglas fir lumber was the major softwood lumber export item at 244 million board feet; hemlock was at 144 million board feet; southern pine at 68 million board feet; and spruce at 60 million board feet.

U.S. softwood log exports, primarily from the Pacific Northwest, were 11.4 percent greater for the first 6 months of 1978 compared to the like period in 1977. Total export volume of softwood logs was 1,718 million board feet. Japan purchased 78 percent of U.S. softwood log exports. The Republic of Korea (South Korea) increased its U.S. softwood log purchases by 250 percent in the first 6 months of 1978 over the same period in 1977, to 225 million board feet or 13 percent of the export volume. Industry sources indicate that Korea's purchases of U.S. softwood logs are ultimately consumed by (1) the domestic market, and (2) the export market, to either Europe or Japan. The lower wage rates of the Korean forest products industry allow these products to be exported competitively with the United States.

Imports of U.S. softwood sawtimber logs were virtually negligible in comparison to consumption at 41 million board feet, for the first 6 months of 1978. Practically all U.S. imports of softwood logs come from Canada. Canada regulates the export of unprocessed softwood logs with the intent to export only softwood logs that are in excess supply of domestic demand. The United

States prohibits the export of softwood logs from Federal lands (basically National Forest lands), but does not prohibit export of logs from State and private lands. Softwood log exports have been controversial in the United States, especially during high domestic demand cycles.

Imports of softwood lumber, on the other hand, consistute a significant proportion of U.S. consumption of that item. For the first 6 months of 1978, Softwood lumber imports amounted to 5,578 million board feet, an increase of 12 percent over the same period last year. Canada continues to dominate the import share with 99 percent of total U.S. purchases of softwood lumber. In the first 6 months of 1978 imports accounted for 27 percent of apparent U.S. domestic consumption. For the first half of 1977, imports of softwood lumber accounted for 25 percent of apparent domestic consumption. The devaluation of the Canadian dollar, low Canadian raw material costs, and relatively cheap transportation, especially from Bri-tish Columbia to eastern U.S. markets, have helped the Canadian exporters market their softwood products in this country.

Softwood plywood production for the first 6 months of 1978 was 10,157 million board feet (3/8-inch basis), a 2 percent increase over the like period in 1977. Shipments of softwood plywood ran slightly less, however, Orders received were 1 percent greater for the first 6 months of this year over the like period last year. Exports of softwood plywood of 176 million square feet were running slightly less than the volume exported by mid-year 1977. The major drop in total volume of softwood plywood exports from 1976 to 1977 of 60 percent was due in major part, to (1) the increase in domestic demand for softwood plywood in 1977-78, (2) the Canadian resolution of Labor disputes in their forest products industry, and (3) the devaluation of the Canadian dollar. Also, the strong market for U.S. plywood in Canada in 1976 quickly diminished in 1977. Imports of softwood plywood are virtually negligible as a part of domestic consumption at 18 million square feet for the first 6 months of this year, and represent less than one-half of one percent of the apparent domestic consumption of softwood plywood.
Softwood lumber Producers Price Index (PPI—formerly Wholesale Price Index) increased 22 percent from

June 1977 to June 1978, and increased 16 percent from December 1977 to June of this year. The relatively high price increases of lumber and plywood compared to the “all commodities” index led to President Carter’s remark in his April 11, 1978, anti-inflation message that directed the U.S. Forest Service, the Bureau of Land Management, and the Council on Environmental Quality to find ways to increase timber sales from Federal lands. Increased timber sales from National Forests would, hopefully, ease supply price pressures on lumber and wood products. Another issue that would potentially affect timber sales volume, is the Road less Area

and Evaluation (RARE II). About 62 million acres of roadless and undeveloped National Forest land are being reviewed under RARE II for the completion of the National Wilderness Preservation System. The RARE II process of land-use planning should be completed by the end of 1978. The industry points to the 26.5 million acres of commerical forest land being reviewed under RARE II as a necessary timber source to meet the projected rising demand for timber products until the end of the century.

Other softwood product PPI'S in June 1978 were millwork at 244.9, a 27 percent increase over June 1977; softwood plywood at 236.0, a 16 percent increase over June 1977; and softwood veneer at 249.1 (1971=100), a 36 percent increase over last year.

The current housing boom was the key factor in price increases to above a 20 percent level in the 1-year period. However, the increasing cost of raw material (the softwood log) to the primary producers of softwood products over the past several years is also an important factor influencing price increases. For instance, U.S. Forest Service statistics show that Douglas fir peeler (used for veneer and eventually plywood) log prices increased on the average from 1971 to 1977 about 19 percent each year to around $300 per thousand board feet. In 1971, Douglas fir peeler logs were selling at $128 per thousand. Douglas fir sawtimber log prices showed an average annual increase of 23.4 percent from 1971 to 1977 or a total of 163.5 percent in the 7-year period. The average price of all grades of Douglas fir sawtimber logs in 1977 was about $227 per MBF.

Prices quoted are for water and inland sales used in domestic consumption. Export sales have generally been at considerably higher prices than domestic sales. In 1977, the price differential between domestic and export log sales was about $85 per thousand board feet for Douglas fir peeler logs, due partly to the higher grade of peeler logs sold for export.
Hardwood lumber production for the first 6 months of 1978 was 3,160 million board feet, about a 5 percent

Prices offered to collectors for ordinary waste news are running from $7 to $12 per ton, compared with a range of $20 to $41 in Jaunary; depending upon metropolitan area or region. At the same time, reported mill buying prices (carload lots f.o.b. dealer's docks) for the somewhat better grade of No. 1 news are reported now to range from $15 to $38 compared with $35 to $85 in January. Old news collections are adequate to meet current requirements. A large supply is available and just waiting for improved demand and more attractive prices to draw it out.

According to industry producer and market sources, the world woodpulp excess inventories, particularly in Swedish pulp export Mills, was drawn down close to normal levels of 1.0 to 1.5 million metric tons by the end of June, from a high of almost 2.9 million metric tons in December 1977. This was accomplished through aggressive market development and competitive pricing by the world market pulp producers. In the soft world market and aggressive selling atmosphere in the first half of the year, U.S. export market pulp lost some ground from volumes shipped during January–June 1977–1.306 million short tons compared with 1.378 million short tons of exports (table S-14). Pulp exports, however, are only a small part (5 percent) of total U.S. pulp production. Market pulp Mills, operating at about 96 percent of capacity during January–June according to the American Paper Institute (API), compared with a 94 percent operating rate during the 1977 period, funneled more of their pulps toward the domstic paper, paperboard and allied products Mills.

Total woodpulp production of captive, or integrated and market pulp Mills is reported at 24 million tons for the first 6 months of 1978, compared with 23.9 million tons for the 1977 period (table S-3). These data, however, are incomplete because the date covering miscellaneous “other” grades of pulp, including defibrated, exploded, screenings and related wood fibers, are not available. The final pulp production figure will probably approach 25.5 million tons for January–June 1977. On an annual basis, pulp production would approximate 51.3 million tons for 1978; up from an estimated 50 plus million tons for 1977, and from 48.8 million tons for 1976. Thus, the pulp industry has been producing to meet a slowly improving demand for its product. Producer inventory data are not yet available from the Bureau of the Census; but API data indicate no inventory building at the pulp Mills. Pulp inventories at the converting Mills also show essentially no change from 1977 levels (table S-4, table S-5).

The leading pulp grades in demand in both domestic and export markets continue to be the bleached and unbleached sulfates (table S-3, table S-14). The total of all sulfate pulp grades, at 18.1 million tons for the first 6 months, was 500,000 tons or 2.8 percent over 1977 sixmonth figures. This tonnage also continues, as in 1977, to represent nearly 75 percent of the total reported 24.0 million tons of pulp production. Production of groundwood grades, including growing volumes of thermomechanical pulps, decreased from 2.3 million tons in the 1977 period to 2.1 million tons for January-June 1978. Semi-chemical pulp production also Fell slightly, from 2.1 million tons to 2.0 million tons for 1978. The production of corrugating medium, based on this pulp, Fell; while the use of wastepapers in a combination furnished medium increased (table S-5). This increased use of wastepaper in combination medium furnishes, especially old corrugated, is reflected in the wastepaper consumption data, by grade (table S-2). Old corrugated consumption at the user Mills, at 2.5 million tons, grew 460,000 tons or 17 percent over 1977 six-month consumption figures.

The production of Special alpha and dissolving pulps dropped slightly from 1977 figures (table S-3). This is reflected in the 8 percent reduced consumption of those grades (table S-5) at the non-paper Mills, where producers of rayon fibers, cellophane and related chemical-converted pulp-based products are being steadily challenged in the market by other man-made fibers, filaments and films. The reduction of Special alpha and dissolving pulp production was also influenced by a drop in exports of these grades from 413,000 tons in January–June 1977 to 403,000 for the 1978 period: a drop of 2.4 percent in exports (table S-14).

The total picture, however, for the pulp producers during January–June 1978 has been one of some improvement. The estimated final 1978 pulp production figure, at 51.3 million tons, will be an all-time record high; close to 2.5 percent above 1977 production. This improvement is geared to the 2.7 percent growth in paper and board production (table S-6).

Practically all U.S. imports of softwood logs come from Canada. Canada regulates the export of unprocessed softwood logs with the intent to export only softwood logs that are in excess supply of domestic demand. The United

States prohibits the export of softwood logs from Federal lands (basically National Forest lands), but does not prohibit export of logs from State and private lands. Softwood log exports have been controversial in the United States, especially during high domestic demand cycles.

Imports of softwood lumber, on the other hand, consistute a significant proportion of U.S. consumption of that item. For the first 6 months of 1978, Softwood lumber imports amounted to 5,578 million board feet, an increase of 12 percent over the same period last year. Canada continues to dominate the import share with 99 percent of total U.S. purchases of softwood lumber. In the first 6 months of 1978 imports accounted for 27 percent of apparent U.S. domestic consumption. For the first half of 1977, imports of softwood lumber accounted for 25 percent of apparent domestic consumption. The devaluation of the Canadian dollar, low Canadian raw material costs, and relatively cheap transportation, especially from Bri-tish Columbia to eastern U.S. markets, have helped the Canadian exporters market their softwood products in this country.

Softwood plywood production for the first 6 months of 1978 was 10,157 million board feet (3/8-inch basis), a 2 percent increase over the like period in 1977. Shipments of softwood plywood ran slightly less, however, Orders received were 1 percent greater for the first 6 months of this year over the like period last year. Exports of softwood plywood of 176 million square feet were running slightly less than the volume exported by mid-year 1977. The major drop in total volume of softwood plywood exports from 1976 to 1977 of 60 percent was due in major part, to (1) the increase in domestic demand for softwood plywood in 1977-78, (2) the Canadian resolution of Labor disputes in their forest products industry, and (3) the devaluation of the Canadian dollar. Also, the strong market for U.S. plywood in Canada in 1976 quickly diminished in 1977. Imports of softwood plywood are virtually negligible as a part of domestic consumption at 18 million square feet for the first 6 months of this year, and represent less than one-half of one percent of the apparent domestic consumption of softwood plywood.
Softwood lumber Producers Price Index (PPI—formerly Wholesale Price Index) increased 22 percent from

June 1977 to June 1978, and increased 16 percent from December 1977 to June of this year. The relatively high price increases of lumber and plywood compared to the “all commodities” index led to President Carter’s remark in his April 11, 1978, anti-inflation message that directed the U.S. Forest Service, the Bureau of Land Management, and the Council on Environmental Quality to find ways to increase timber sales from Federal lands. Increased timber sales from National Forests would, hopefully, ease supply price pressures on lumber and wood products. Another issue that would potentially affect timber sales volume, is the Road less Area

and Evaluation (RARE II). About 62 million acres of roadless and undeveloped National Forest land are being reviewed under RARE II for the completion of the National Wilderness Preservation System. The RARE II process of land-use planning should be completed by the end of 1978. The industry points to the 26.5 million acres of commerical forest land being reviewed under RARE II as a necessary timber source to meet the projected rising demand for timber products until the end of the century.

Other softwood product PPI'S in June 1978 were millwork at 244.9, a 27 percent increase over June 1977; softwood plywood at 236.0, a 16 percent increase over June 1977; and softwood veneer at 249.1 (1971=100), a 36 percent increase over last year.

The current housing boom was the key factor in price increases to above a 20 percent level in the 1-year period. However, the increasing cost of raw material (the softwood log) to the primary producers of softwood products over the past several years is also an important factor influencing price increases. For instance, U.S. Forest Service statistics show that Douglas fir peeler (used for veneer and eventually plywood) log prices increased on the average from 1971 to 1977 about 19 percent each year to around $300 per thousand board feet. In 1971, Douglas fir peeler logs were selling at $128 per thousand. Douglas fir sawtimber log prices showed an average annual increase of 23.4 percent from 1971 to 1977 or a total of 163.5 percent in the 7-year period. The average price of all grades of Douglas fir sawtimber logs in 1977 was about $227 per MBF.

Prices quoted are for water and inland sales used in domestic consumption. Export sales have generally been at considerably higher prices than domestic sales. In 1977, the price differential between domestic and export log sales was about $85 per thousand board feet for Douglas fir peeler logs, due partly to the higher grade of peeler logs sold for export.

Venezuela has begun a number of large forestry projects to satisfy the fiber requirements of that nation's pulp and paper Mills. Raw material needs are particularly acute with respect to secondary fibers for the paper and board industry, long-fibered pulp for newsprint, and softwood timber for use in the construction industry. The pulp and paper industry is heavily dependent on imports, with 83 percent of all pulp requirements being imported. As these projects reach maturity, opportunities for U.S. businessmen will arise in construction, consulting/engineering, and equipment sales.

Because of current pulp, short fiber, and timber shortages, Venezuela has embarked on an ambitious planting/development program for Caribbean pine and eucalyptus in the southern Anzoategui and northern Monagas State areas, respectively. The objective is to convert the Sabanas into a gigantic forestry and industry complex capable of supporting several pulp Mills that would not only supply domestic needs but also provide valuable export income. The two major government agencies responsible for these developments are Corporacion Venezolana de Guayana (CVG) and Compania Nacional de Reforestacion (CNR).

was begun in 1969 by Corporacion Venezolana de Guayana with the intention of planting 218 million trees on 150,000 hectares by 1985, in order to produce long fiber pulp-mainly for the production of newsprint. Long fiber pulp is currently imported at an annual rate of 80,000 tons. Caribbean pine (Hondurensis), imported from Guatemala and other Central American countries, is the type of tree being planted. To date, about 80 million trees have been planted on 110,000 acres, with an additional 110 million planned for 1984. Plans are being made to harvest trees for pulp production in 1984. Eventually, 4,000 hectares out of every 10,000 will be harvested for pulp, with the remainder being conserved for timber production (maturity: about 10 to 15 years). By 1986, CVG expects to reach the 4,000 hectare level, with an expected yield of 180 cubic meters per hectare. CVG will require forestry equipment and technical assistance for the extraction process.

In preparation for the harvesting period, CVG has plans to build a pulp mill capable of producing 200,000 tons annually, which should be completed by the 1984 deadline. Decisions on outside equity participation and exact composition have yet to be made, but the mill will be separately managed from the rest of the forestry

ect, and probably will be structured in the manner of other CVG corporations such as SIDOR, VENALUM. and ALCASE. While a feasibility study had been made at the initial conception of the Uverito Forestry

it considered tropical woods rather than pines as the basic raw material. A probable timetable for Uverito development is: late 1978-79 for new feasibility studies; 1979-81 for decisions on equity participation; 1981-82 for start of construction; and 1984 for start-up of production.

Compania Nacional de Reforestacion (CONARE) was created in August 1975, with the mandate to take responsibility for Venezuela's forestry industry (excluding Uverito). Under Federal decree No. 1341 of December 16, 1975, CONARE was authorized to incorporate the private sector into Venezuela's forestry programs. While CONARE has several small experimental forests throughout the country, its major area of development is in South Anzoategui and Monagas States, on land owned by the National Agrarian Institute. Here CONARE has about 100,000 hectares which it plans to divide into seven huge blocks and to develop, in conjunction with its Venezuelan and foreign partners, a large Caribbean pine and eucalyptus plantation.

Companies established by CONARE include: (1) Corporacion Forestal Guayamure, with an area of about 10,000 hectares of Caribbean pine; (2) Forestor, with an area of 75,000 hectares which will be planted to eucalyptus to support a 300,000 ton-year pulp mill; and (3) Corporacion Forestal Sipao S.A., which will plant 18,000 hectares of short-fibered eucalyptus.
Corporation Venezolana de Fomento is doing a feasibility study for a bagasse mill at Rio Turbio. Industry
sources are skeptical of this project's success, in part due to water shortages in the area. A
to construct a short fiber mill in Central Portuguesa is also being considered. While no construction has begun, several firms have placed orders for its production.
With harvesting periods due around 1984, and with initial experimental thinnings already started, the demand for forestry equipment should begin to increase. The manager of the Uverito Forestry
has already visited the United States to study equipment. The proximity of the United States, which facilitates maintenance, is an important competitive factor.

In response to the upcoming increases in supply of raw materials there appears to be a new interest in investment in paper machines; several local firms are considering purchases of new machines in the near future. However, industry members are awaiting changes in Government price control policy before making large investments.
Forestry studies have indicated the need for improved planting methods. Consequently, there should be new purchases of equipment to plant and maintain forests. A Georgia
has already sold quite a few of its semiautomatic transplanters to CONARE, Uverito, and Manpa paper

There has been considerable discussion concerning the placing of Venezuela's forest and pulp industry under one government coordinating agency. Since most of the forestry projects are located in the same area (southern Anzoategui, Monagas, and Uverito) coordination between the entities developing these areas will be required for long-term investments such as pulp Mills. Plans call for a ministerial level commission to coordinate forestry development between Uverito, CONARE, and the private sector. It is reported that the Government is considering consolidating the industry under CONARE'S manageIn ent.

Australian Newsprint Mills Ltd. (ANM) has announced a go-ahead for construction of a A$155 million newsprint mill at Albury, in New South Wales. The New South Wales Government had encouraged the construction of the mill with various incentives, including housing, payroll tax rebates, machinery subsidies, employee training subsidies, and financial assistance in locating key perSonnel.

The mill will eventually have the capacity to produce 180,000 tons of newsprint a year, raising ANM'S total annual capacity to more than 380,000 tons. More than 90 percent of the raw material furnished would be thermomechanical pulp produced at the mill; the remainder will be imported in the form of bleached sulfate pulp. About 450,000 cubic meters-year of radiata pine is available from about 53,000 hectares of State-owned forest in the area around Albury. ANM presently operates a newsprint mill in Tasmania, and the combined production from both Mills would satisfy about 70 percent of Australia's annual newsprint consumption. This will reduce the country's dependence on imported newsprint— about 200,000 tons annually, mainly from New
and Canada—and will save about A$70 million in foreign exchange.
The planning and design of the mill is well under way, and the selection of equipment has reached an advanced

which is due for completion in 1981, has been welcomed by state and local governments of New South Wales, although there have been some protests from a wide range of community groups, following environmental and economic impact studies on the proposed mill. The

will provide employment for about 800 people during the construction phase, and 650 people when in actual operation. It has been reported that about A-100 million will be borrowed from domestic sources for the
by ANM, with additional capital sought overseas.
The decision by ANM to construct the new mill at Albury could put the

in direct competition with one of its major shareholders, New Zealand's Tasman Pulp and Paper Co. Ltd., which has a 16 percent stake in ANM (ANM also has a 20 percent share in Tasman Pulp and Paper). The New

is a major producer and supplier of newsprint to Australia, and has been in Some financial difficulties of late. Sources: American Embassy report dated July 1978; industry trade journal reports dated August and September 1978.

Gautemala does not produce its own woodpulp, satisfying all of its primary papermaking fiber requirements through imports. Industria Papelera Centro Americana, the largest of the country's three paper pro
ducers, was sold recently by Boise Cascade Corporation of the United States to the Sigma Group of El Salvador; the latter is a large printing and packaging materials
pany with manufacturing operations in Mexico and Central America. Industria Papelera reported production of 25,000 tons of paper in 1977, up by almost one-third over 1976, when the

imported 10,800 tons of pulp, including bleached and semi-bleached sulfate, all from the United States. The remainder of their fiber needs came from wastepaper, of which a total of 12,500 tons were used. This included 6,500 tons from the United States, and 6,000 tons collected in Guatemala.

Papeles Elaborados reported that it produced about 7,000 tons of paper in 1977, up from 5,000 tons in 1976. A new paper machine is now in operation at the company's mill. The firm has indicated that it imports about 2,800 tons of U.S. pulp and uses about 4,200 tons of wastepaper, of which, about 40 percent is obtained locally and the remainder from other Central American countries. Cartones Economicos is a small producer of grey board, with an annual output of 600 tons.

The most interesting year-to-year change in 1977 was the extraordinary increase in the consumption of paper in Guatemala, rising from 56,000 tons to more than 97,500 during the 1976-77 period. Imports of paper climbed from 40,500 tons to 75,861 tons, while exports were static at about 11,000 tons.
Source: American Embassy Guatemala report dated July 1978.
3. Indonesia: Report on Two Wood-Processing Complexes: P.T. Raja Garuda Mas and the Plywood Oligopoly

The wood-processing complex of P.T. Raja Garuda Mas is located at Besitong in North Sumatra province near the border with Aceh. Established in 1974, the firm began operations with only a plywood mill but, in the intervening years, has added two sawmill units and a plant which produces wood-cement panels for prefabricated houses.

In addition to plywood for construction purposes, the facility also turns out decorative veneer for furniture. Most of the equipment in the plywood plant is of Japanese manufacture though there were two large peelers from a U.S. manufacturer, Production Machinery Inc. of Portland, Oregon. Capacity of the plywood operation is 12,000-15,000 sheets (measuring four feet by eight feet, with a thickness of four millimeters) per day. The plant operates 24 hours per day with the exception of 2 days each month when shut down for maintenance.
Garuda Mas' sawmill units were set up in 1977 to
comply with an Indonesian Government regulation compelling holders of timber concessions to process logs locally. As at the plywood facility, most of the equipment was imported from Japan.

began to manufacture wood-cement panels using as raw material the waste from its plywood and sawmill operations. Wood waste is chipped in a hammer mill, and is washed and mixed with cement to produce panels measuring one meter by twenty centimeters, with a thickness of five centimeters. These panels are used principally in the construction of low-cost, prefabricated houses. At present Garuda Mas produces about 3,000 panels per day.

Garuda Mas obtains its timber from large concessions controlled by the firm in Aceh province, near the town of Idi. Logs are floated down the Besitong River to the plant site on the river bank. The river also serves as the company's inlet for imported raw materials, which are brought in by barge, mainly from Singapore. Most of the finished products are trucked to Medan's port, Belawan, for shipment to Java or abroad.

Established in 1974, Lontar Papyrus Paper Industry is situated in Aceh province, about twenty kilometers from the town of Langsa. The sole owner of the facility is a Medan resident of Chinese descent. Except for two technicians from Taiwan, the plant is staffed by local Indonesians. Much of the plant's equipment, which appears quite modern, is from Taiwan, though there is some from Japan and West Germany as well. Raw material, in the form of boxed pulp, is imported from the Scandinavian countries, Canada and the United States. Originally, the firm had hoped to procure most of its raw material locally but it discovered that it could obtain only enough wood to operate its chippers at 20 percent capacity. The

now hopes to arrange with one or more local timber companies to obtain the waste wood from logging operations for use in paper production. Lontar has no timber concession of its own. Present capacity of the Lontar operation is 30 tons per day, all of which is marketed in the Medan area. The plant produces paper with tensile strength from 28 to 70 grams. Reportedly, the

has no difficulty in selling all of the paper it makes during its round-the-clock operations. About 200 people are employed at the plant. Within the next year Lontar plans to expand its capacity to 100 tons per day. Land adjacent to the existing plant has been cleared and equipment for the expansion is on order. The firm plans to market part of its increased
